content.title: Planck Stars: Quantum Gravity Alternative to Black Hole Singularities
content.summary: Planck stars are hypothetical quantum gravitational objects that may form inside black holes when collapsing matter reaches Planck density. They represent a proposed resolution to the black hole information paradox.

concept.description: When matter collapses to form a black hole, classical general relativity predicts a singularity of infinite density. However, at Planck density ρ_P ~ 10⁹³ kg/m³, quantum gravity effects become dominant and may halt the collapse, forming a 'Planck star'.
concept.key_idea: Quantum pressure from spacetime discreteness or uncertainty prevents further collapse

bounce_time.formula: τ ~ M/m_P × t_P (in proper time of infalling matter)
bounce_time.external_time: τ_ext ~ M³/m_P² × t_P (extremely long for large M)
bounce_time.interpretation: External observers see collapse 'frozen' at horizon

loop_quantum_gravity.prediction: Matter bounces at Planck density, re-expands

causal_structure.after_bounce: Possible white hole or explosive release

observational_signatures.description: Planck star explosions could produce distinctive GRB signatures
observational_signatures.detectability: Potentially observable for primordial black holes

observational_signatures.description: Some FRBs might be Planck star emissions

comparison_to_alternatives.singularity: Classical GR - infinite density, information destroyed
comparison_to_alternatives.firewall: Quantum effects at horizon - drama for infalling observer
comparison_to_alternatives.fuzzball: String theory - horizon replaced by stringy structure
comparison_to_alternatives.planck_star: LQG - bounce at Planck density, no singularity

open_questions: What is the exact mechanism of the quantum bounce?
How long does the Planck star phase last?
What is the fate of information during and after bounce?
Are there observable signatures distinguishing from classical BH?
